display_title.display_title:
México - Segundo Proyecto de
            Rehabilitación de Carreteras: Evaluación social

docna.cdata!:
Mexico - Second Highway Rehabilitation
            Project : social assessment

repnme.cdata!:
Mexico - Second Highway Rehabilitation
            Project : social assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
This social assessment (SA) examines the
            possibility of negative impacts as a result of the Second
            Highways Rehabilitation Project, particularly regarding
            potential involuntary resettlement by indigenous
            populations, since marginal groups were identified, namely
            few indigenous populations, migrant rural workers, and small
            suburban communities, who could suffer adverse social
            impacts. However, the report stipulates that the right of
            way will not be affected, i.e., resettlement issues
            resulting from land acquisition will not occur, since
            basically, the federal road network encompasses already
            developed urban areas. Furthermore, the Ministry of
            Communications and Transport should provide progress reports
            on the implementation of each subproject in compliance with
            the right of way, and, relevant information on the traffic
            generated should be made available, to estimate beneficial,
            or negative impacts on local populations, a measure which
            should be incorporated in all roads and highway projects. In
            addition, the SA indicates that highway projects mostly
            generate beneficial social aspects, since they improve the
            economy, as commercial activity increases; promote cultural
            activities, as regional, national, and international tourism
            increases; and, improve social aspects, as increased access
            to education, health, and social benefits facilitate the
            well-being of distant populations.
